case_name: Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co., Ltd. v. the respondents

facts.text: Appeal is C.A. No. 305 of 1964 by Special Leave from the order dated 9th April 1963 of the Labour Court Coimbatore in C.S.O. Appeal No. 1 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 305 of 1964. Appeal by Special Leave from the order dated the 9th April, 1963 of the Labour Court, Coimbatore, in C.S.O. Appeal No. 1 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant is Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd., a licensee under the Indian Electricity Act 1910.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Gajendragadkar, C.J. The appellant, Salem Erode Electricity Distribution Co., Ltd., is a licensee under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910,

facts.text: Appellant's business consists in buying electrical energy in bulk from the State Electricity Board of Madras and selling it to consumers in Salem and Erode and certain rural districts in the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: and its business companysists in buying electrical energy in bulk from the State Electricity Board of Madras and selling it to companysumers in Salem and Erode and certain rural districts in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Appellant has an industrial establishment at Salem.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of carrying on this business, the appellant has an industrial establishment at Salem.

facts.text: In or about 1940, appellant's consumers numbered about 3000 and workmen about 45, and appellant framed terms and conditions of employment including leave and holidays.

anchor.surface_text: In or about 1940, when the number of the appellants company- sumers was about 3,000, and that of its workmen about 45, the appellant framed certain terms and companyditions of its workmens employment. Amongst these were included terms about leave and holidays.

facts.text: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act 1946 came into force, and provisions as to leave and holidays were embodied in appellant's Standing Orders certified under the Act in or about 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Later, when the Industrial Employment  Standing Orders  Act, 1946  No. 20 of 1946   hereinafter called the Act  came into force, the provisions as to leave and holidays which had been introduced by the appellant in the terms and companyditions of the employment of its workmen, were embodied in the appellants Standing Orders which were certified under the relevant provisions of the Act in or about 1947.

facts.text: Standing Order 5(b): The number of holidays to be granted to the workmen and the days which shall be observed as holidays by the Establishment shall be regulated in accordance with the Factories Act 1948 or other relevant law for time being in force and the custom or usage of the Establishment viz holidays under the Negotiable Instruments Act 1881 and festival holidays peculiar to this locality which are being given.

anchor.surface_text: The said terms read thus - Standing Order 5 b  The number of holidays to be granted to the workmen and the days which shall be observed as holidays by the Establishment shall be regulated in accordance with the Factories Act, 1948 or other relevant law for time being in force and the custom or usage of the Establishment, viz., holidays under the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 and festival holidays peculiar to this locality which are being given.

facts.text: Standing Order 10(a): Leave will be given in accordance with the law and existing practice provided the leave facilities number available to the workers are number curtailed in any manner.

anchor.surface_text: 5 0 0 Standing Order 10 a  Leave will be given in accordance with the law and existing practice provided the leave facilities number available to the workers are number curtailed in any manner.

facts.text: Appellant made application on 6th October 1960 before Certifying Officer Madras for amendment of certified Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings which have, given rise to the present appeal by special leave between the appellant and the respondents, its employees, began with the application made by -the appellant on the 6th October, 1960, before the Certifying Officer, Madras, for the amendment of the certified Standing Orders to which we have just referred.

facts.text: Appellant proposed amendment to Standing Order 5(b): For all workmen who have joined service prior to [date] holidays under Negotiable Instruments Act 1881 and festival holidays of one day per year which day may be chosen by the workmen shall be given. For all who joined on and after [date] holidays under Madras Industrial Establishments (National and Festival holidays) Act 1958 shall be given.

anchor.surface_text: By its application, the management of the appellant wanted the said Orders to read thus Standing Order 5 b  For all workmen who have joined service prior to holidays under the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, and festival holidays of one day per year which day may be chosen by the workmen shall be given. For all workmen who have joined on and after holidays under the Madras Industrial Establishments  National and Festival holidays  Act, 1958 shall be given.

facts.text: Appellant proposed amendment to Standing Order 10(a): Leave will be given to all employees appointed on and after [date] in accordance with Madras Shops and Establishments Act 1947 or modification thereof irrespective of applicability. Provided for confirmed employees prior to date leave facilities not curtailed.

anchor.surface_text: Standing Order 10 a  Leave will be given to all employees who are appointed on and after iii accordance with the provisions of the Madras Shops and Establishment Act, 1947 or any statutory modification thereof  irrespective of whether this Act applies or number to any category of employee or employees . Provided, however, that for all employees who have been companyfirmed prior to the above said date, viz the leave facilities number available are number curtailed in any manner.

facts.text: Appellant introduced revised rules on 1st October 1960 embodied in contracts of new entrants who agreed to them.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that these Rules were introduced by the appellant on the 1st October, 1960, and were embodied in the companytracts of service of new entrants who joined the appellants employment as from that date. In fact, they were agreed to by such new entrants.

facts.text: Respondents Union resisted proposed changes as unfair unreasonable introducing discrimination between employees causing unrest.

anchor.surface_text: The change proposed to be made by the appellant in the two Standing Orders in question was resisted by the respondents Union. It was urged by the respondents that the proposed change was unfair and unreasonable, and it was also argued that it would introduce discrimination between one set of employees and another working under the same employer, and that would naturally cause industrial unrest and disharmony.

facts.text: Certifying Officer upheld respondents' pleas and negatived proposed amendments.

anchor.surface_text: The Certifying Officer upheld the pleas raised by the respondents and he accordingly directed that the proposed amendments should be negatived.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to appellate authority which agreed with Certifying Officer and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred an appeal against the said order before the appellate authority. Both the parties urged similar companytentions before the appellate authority and the said authority agreed with the view taken by the Certifying Officer and dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against appellate authority's order.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Appellant argued change fair reasonable bona fides by applying only to future entrants.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Setalvad has urged that the change which the appellant wants to make in the two relevant orders is, on the merits, fair and reasonable and he adds that the appellant wanted to prove its bona fides by making the changed Standing Orders applicable to the future entrants and number extending them to its employees who were already in its employment and who are governed by the existing Standing Orders.

facts.text: Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act 1946 passed in 1946 to require employers to define terms and conditions formally.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1946 and its main object was to require the employers in industrial establishments to which the Act applied, to define formally the terms and companyditions of employment in their respective establishments.

facts.text: Act amended in 1956 conferring jurisdiction on Certifying Officer and appellate authority to adjudicate fairness or reasonableness of Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: By an amendment made in 1956, jurisdiction has been companyferred on the Certifying Officer as well as the appellate authority to adjudicate upon the fairness or reasonableness of the provisions of the Standing Orders submitted for certification.

facts.text: Section 10(2) amended in 1956 to allow workmen to apply for modification of Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: By the amendment made in 1956, even workmen are number entitled to apply for the modification of the Standing Orders.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds two sets of Standing Orders cannot be certified under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, this argument appears to be attractive but if we examine the scheme of the relevant Provisions of the Act in the light of the matters specified in the schedule in respect of which Standing Orders are required to be made, it appears that two sets of Standing Orders cannot be made under the Act.

facts.text: Certifying Officer and appellate authority did not err in refusing to certify modified Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we do number think that Mr. Setalvad is right in companytending that the Certifying Officer as well as the appellate authority erred in law in refusing to certify the modified Standing Orders submitted by the appellant for certification.

anchor.surface_text: Standing Orders are defined by s. 2 g as meaning rules relating to matters set out in the Schedule these matters are 11 in number, and the last one of them refers to any other matter which may be prescribed Prescribed according to s. 2 f

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 requires that the Standing Orders must deal with every matter set out in the Schedule which is applicable to the industrial establishment, and must be in companyformity with the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Object of Act is uniformity of terms and conditions for workmen in same category doing same work

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed in 1946 and its main object was to require the employers in industrial establishments to which the Act applied, to define formally the terms and companyditions of employment in their respective establishments.

arguments.claim: Two sets of Standing Orders would lead to confusion, dissatisfaction, and potentially multiple sets over time

anchor.surface_text: It is number difficult to imagine how the application of two sets of Standing Orders in respect of the said matters is bound to lead to companyfusion in the working of the establishment and cause dissatisfaction amongst the employees.

arguments.claim: Rai Bahadur Diwan Badri Das case does not assist as it dealt with industrial dispute under different Act, not certification under IESOA

anchor.surface_text: In that case, the Court was dealing with an award pronounced by an Industrial Tribunal in an industrial dispute and the narrow question which the Court decided was that the Industrial Tribunal was number in error in number upholding the rule made by the employer

arguments.claim: Associated Cement case concerns comprehensive consideration in wage disputes, not applicable to certification of two sets

anchor.surface_text: But these companysiderations do number arise in the present proceedings, because what the appropriate authorities under the Act had to companysider was whether two sets of Standing Orders should be permitted under the same establishment or number.

arguments.claim: Guest Keen case not applicable as it concerned application to prior employees in industrial dispute, not certification of two sets

anchor.surface_text: As we have already pointed out, the question as to whether two sets of Standing Orders can be certified under the provisions of the Act, did number fall to be companysidered in that case.

arguments.claim: Certifying Officer and appellate authority committed no error in refusing to certify modified Standing Orders

anchor.surface_text: That is why we do number think that Mr. Setalvad is right in companytending that the Certifying Officer as well as the appellate authority erred in law in refusing to certify the modified Standing Orders submitted by the appellant for certification.

holdings.text: It is not permissible for an industrial establishment to have two sets of Standing Orders to govern the relevant terms and conditions of its employees under the Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, this argument appears to be attractive but if we examine the scheme of the relevant Provisions of the Act in the light of the matters specified in the schedule in respect of which Standing Orders are required to be made, it appears that two sets of Standing Orders cannot be made under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of the Act, definition of Standing Orders in s.2(g), requirement in s.4 to cover all Schedule matters applicable to the establishment, and nature of Schedule items (e.g., classification, leave) preclude two sets; purpose is uniformity for all workmen to avoid ad hoc terms and confusion.

holdings.text: Standing Orders certified under the Act must be uniform and applicable to all workmen alike in the industrial establishment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of Schedule clauses shows no scope for separate Standing Orders by date of entry; Act aims to replace ad hoc oral terms with formal uniform conditions known beforehand.

holdings.text: The Certifying Officer and appellate authority did not err in law in refusing to certify the proposed modified Standing Orders.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we do not think that Mr. Setalvad is right in contending that the Certifying Officer as well as the appellate authority erred in law in refusing to certify the modified Standing Orders submitted by the appellant for certification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proposed amendments would create two sets prohibited by Act's scheme; fairness/reasonableness irrelevant to permissibility of dual sets.

holdings.text: The present decision does not address whether disputes regarding certified Standing Orders can be referred for adjudication under s.10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Scope of appeal limited to certification under IESOA; IDA reference issue left open.

precedents.citation: Rai Bahadur Diwan Badri Das v. The Industrial Tribunal, Punjab 1 1963 3 S.CR. 930

anchor.surface_text: In Rai Bahadur Diwan Badri Das v. The Industrial Tribunal, Punjab 1 , this Court had to companysider the question as to whether the Tribunal against whose award an appeal had been brought to this Court by the appellant Rai Bahadur Diwan Badri Das was in error in refusing to allow the appellants prayer that he should be permitted to introduce a new rule in respect of leave with wages applicable to the entrants in his employment after the 1st of July, 1956.

precedents.case_name: Rai Bahadur Diwan Badri Das v Industrial Tribunal Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: employer permitted to introduce new rule on leave with wages for entrants after specific date without affecting prior employees
precedents.cited_holding: Tribunal not in error in holding uniformity of conditions of service including earned leave for all employees

precedents.citation: Associated Cement Staff Union and Another v. Associated Cement Company and Others 1 1963 3 S.C.R 348 1964 1 L.L.J. 12

anchor.surface_text: The next decision to which Mr. Setalvad has referred was pronounced by this Court in the case of Associated Cement Staff Union and Another v. Associated Cement Company and Others 1 . During the companyrse of the hearing of this appeal, some arguments were urged before us on the question about the relation between terms and companyditions of service governing working hours, leave, and the like, and the wages paid to the employees.

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Staff Union v Associated Cement Company
precedents.cited_proposition: normal working hours and holidays can be fixed by industrial adjudication without sole regard to overtime wages entitlement
precedents.cited_holding: number of holidays reduced from 21 to 16 and working hours fixed considering relevant factors beyond overtime pay

precedents.citation: Guest, Keen, William Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling and Others 1 1960 1 S.C.R. 348

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which reference must be made is Guest, Keen, William Private Ltd. v. P. J. Sterling and Others 1 . In that case, the Standing Order had been certified under the Act prior to its amendment. The relevant Standing Order had relation to the age of retirement of the employees under the establishment in question.

precedents.case_name: Guest Keen Williams Private Ltd v P J Sterling
precedents.cited_proposition: certified standing order on age of retirement does not apply to existing employees but can be prescribed via industrial adjudication
precedents.cited_holding: certified standing order could not affect rights of previous employees but age of superannuation fixed at 60 years under special circumstances

outcome.relief_summary: Refusal of Certifying Officer and appellate authority to certify the proposed modified Standing Orders upheld; appellant's appeal dismissed
